issue.title: Parsing SciPy TODO list

labels.name: SciPy
labels.description: issues related to enable LFortran to compile the entire FORTRAN codebase in SciPy

issue.body:
The following `lfortran --show-ast --fixed-form $file > $file.ast` now works for every `*.f` file in SciPy, except the following three issues:

* [x] include statements (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/777)
* [x] data in body (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/778)
* [x] else syntax (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/779)

After resolving those three issues, here is a TODO list:

* [x] Get formatting working for all files: `lfortran --fixed-form fmt --no-color $file > $file.f90`
    * [x]  https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/782
* [x] Use gfortran to compile the `.f90` files generated in the previous step instead of the original `.f` files.
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/781
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/784
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/785
* [x] Link everything with SciPy (still use f2py with the original `.f` files) and ensure everything builds
* [ ] Ensure all tests pass if we build all`.f` files via LFortran -> GFortran
* [ ] I also want to check that the f90 can be parsed with LFortran

This would be a very solid test that we have parsed everything correctly to AST (and can format everything correctly); everything that is tested by SciPy tests at least.

body:
I'm pretty sure it's just the indentation that's off. The entire block is

```fortran
       IF (N.GE.2.AND.N.LE.INT(0.9*X)) THEN
           F0=BJV0
           F1=BJV1
           DO 45 K=2,N
              F=2.0D0*(K+V0-1.0D0)/X*F1-F0
              F0=F1
              F1=F
45            VL(K)=F
        ELSE IF (N.GE.2) THEN
           M=MSTA1(X,200)
           IF (M.LT.N) THEN
              N=M
           ELSE
              M=MSTA2(X,N,15)
           ENDIF
           F=0.0D0
           F2=0.0D0
           F1=1.0D-100
           DO 50 K=M,0,-1
              F=2.0D0*(V0+K+1.0D0)/X*F1-F2
              IF (K.LE.N) VL(K)=F
              F2=F1
50            F1=F
           CS=0.0D0
           IF (DABS(BJV0).GT.DABS(BJV1)) CS=BJV0/F
           ELSE CS=BJV1/F2
           DO 55 K=0,N
55            VL(K)=CS*VL(K)
        ENDIF
```

The entire block starts with `IF () THEN` then `ELSE IF () THEN` then `ELSE` -- the single-line `IF` is just confusing but I think what you're proposing is not the actual behavior of the code. I will explore this a little later but I don't think you can chain single-line `IF` statements with other conditionals.

This is a bug in scipy, I think Ondrej's proposed fix is the intended implementation, while the actual implementation uses

```f90
cs = 0.0d0
if (abs(bjv0) > abs(bjv1)) cs = bjv0 / f
elsecs = bjv1 / f2
```

Note that the “else” branch will never be reached because it is an assignment to the implicitly typed variable `elsecs`, which remains unused in the later code.

issue.title: BUG? Incorrect branch in `LAMV` / `_specfunc.lamv`

labels.name: defect
labels.description: A clear bug or issue that prevents SciPy from being installed or used as expected

labels.name: Fortran
labels.description: Items related to the internal Fortran code base

issue.body:
### Description

Due to implicit typing and insignificant whitespace in fixed format Fortran the following lines in the `LAMV` implementation provide an *if* branch but no *else* branch.

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/dd153ceab933e74ab33c9391445dc8686c28479a/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f#L2764-L2765

What looks like an *else* branch is actually an assignment to the implicitly typed variable *elsecs* and has no effect on the implementation of `LAMV`.

### Potential fix

**Change to intended behavior**

```diff
diff --git a/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f b/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
index eed084d4c..3c7cc1c45 100644
--- a/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
+++ b/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
@@ -2761,8 +2761,11 @@ C
               F2=F1
 50            F1=F
            CS=0.0D0
-           IF (DABS(BJV0).GT.DABS(BJV1)) CS=BJV0/F
-           ELSE CS=BJV1/F2
+           IF (DABS(BJV0).GT.DABS(BJV1)) THEN
+              CS=BJV0/F
+           ELSE
+              CS=BJV1/F2
+           ENDIF
            DO 55 K=0,N
 55            VL(K)=CS*VL(K)
         ENDIF
```

**Clarify actual behavior**

```diff
diff --git a/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f b/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
index eed084d4c..4edcf5ee2 100644
--- a/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
+++ b/scipy/special/specfun/specfun.f
@@ -2762,7 +2762,6 @@ C
 50            F1=F
            CS=0.0D0
            IF (DABS(BJV0).GT.DABS(BJV1)) CS=BJV0/F
-           ELSE CS=BJV1/F2
            DO 55 K=0,N
 55            VL(K)=CS*VL(K)
         ENDIF
```

### Related

Found in https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/779

issue.title: FIX: special: use intended branching for `lamv` implementation

labels.name: defect
labels.description: A clear bug or issue that prevents SciPy from being installed or used as expected

labels.name: Fortran
labels.description: Items related to the internal Fortran code base

issue.body:
<!-- 
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure that
your PR satisfies the checklist before submitting:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#checklist-before-submitting-a-pr

Also, please name and describe your PR as you would write a
commit message:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message

Note that we are a team of volunteers; we appreciate your
patience during the review process.

Again, thanks for contributing!
-->

#### Reference issue
<!--Example: Closes gh-WXYZ.-->
Closes https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/17104

#### What does this implement/fix?
<!--Please explain your changes.-->
Change `lamv` implementation to use intended branching for assignment to variable `cs` and avoid useless assignment to implicitly typed variable `elsecs`.

#### Additional information
<!--Any additional information you think is important.-->
See https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/779

body: While the code in scipy is incorrect, the required change for LFortran would be to identify the implicitly typed variable *elsecs* and perform the assignment. A diagnostic in the fixed format parser when ignoring non-significant whitespace might be useful, in most cases this is likely to be a programmer error.

rename.from: Implement single line if and else combination
rename.to: Ignore non-significant whitespace in fixed format parser

body:
Ha, amazing!!

@jacobwilliams, @fortranfan you will both love this, another example of the default Fortran behavior causing a bug, and there being no issue with backwards compatibility (for SciPy) due to the fact that LFortran currently can't handle a variable `elsecs` in fixed form. For the background: in the last couple days I got our fixed-form parser parse all of SciPy, and I noted a few things that still need fixing, such as the `elsecs` issue, you can see it in my comment here: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/blob/41532ef8f936b9b7f86d07c3f7a402681eb67f18/src/lfortran/parser/fixedform_tokenizer.cpp#L1181, I am aware of it, but wanted to first parse SciPy, then worry about these corner cases. Due to this, LFortran currently refuses to compile `elsecs`, and it turns out this was an actual bug in SciPy.... 

Obviously we'll "fix" it in LFortran, as we want to parse code according to the standard.

However, probably adding some optional warnings for such usage might be very helpful to catch bugs. Of course, I don't know if it is worth investing more into fixed-form, as I really want to focus my efforts into free-form, where this particular issue does not happen. The only advantage would be to catch bugs in existing fixed-form code, such as the above bug.

Let me know your thoughts.
Amazing @awvwgk this can already be merged! Nice.

@Thirumalai-Shaktivel since you wrote most of the parser as well as the AST->f90 formatter, you will be happy to hear that there was not a single bug! Everything worked on the first try, once I provided a correct fixed-form tokenizer. The Bison parser worked, the fmt worked, and gfortran could compile the newly generated free-form source. Great job, I really appreciated your diligent focus on detail that made this possible. The LFortran's parser and formatter seems very solid. Thank you!
Ug, this is the perfect storm of Fortran 77 nonsense!
That's great news! I'm glad that our LFortran parser has become very strong.

> Ha, amazing!!
> 
> .. @FortranFan you will both love this, another example of the default Fortran behavior causing a bug, and there being no issue with backwards compatibility (for SciPy) due to the fact that LFortran currently can't handle a variable `elsecs` in fixed form. For the background: in the last couple days I got our fixed-form parser parse all of SciPy, and I noted a few things that still need fixing, such as the `elsecs` issue, you can see it in my comment here:
> ..
> Let me know your thoughts.


Thanks for sharing @certik .  Interesting situation and disappointing also since it reminds us all about the certain intransigent positions when it comes to moving forward to overcome the limitations with legacy semantics in `Fortran`.

For the immediate situation with `specfun.f` in SciPy, both you and @awvwgk have converged on the right approach.

For the longer term, I wonder whether we can review the special functions of interest to SciPy and cross-check against the current Fortran standard (it already includes support for various aspects including Bessel functions) and also the Fortran `stdlib` efforts.

Ultimately it will be good if the base Fortran language includes as much support as reasonable toward special functions followed by robust coverage in the Fortran `stdlib` to arrive at a point where SciPy may feel compelled to do away with the legacy FORTRAN implementation in `specfun.f` and move to modern Fortran solutions instead, notwithstanding their own backward compatibility challenges with their poorly written code in their `FORTRAN` libraries.

By the way, do you have any info on the genesis of `specfun.f`?  How did it get authored, under whose influence, and when?  It appears to have been written in not too distant past i.e., after the Fortran 90/95 standard revision and in which case it is disappointing it did not use any of the good coding practices made possible with Fortran 90/95.
